course_title: Ancient World Study Tour and Field School

learning_outcomes.description: Recognise, describe, and contextualise key features of the history, architecture, material culture, and landscape of ancient Rome and Italy.
Relate archaeological, material, and topographic evidence to major historical events, personalities, and institutions in the Roman world.
Understand the ways in which the later use, restoration, and reception of ancient remains shapes our understanding of ancient art, architecture, and culture.

assessments.task_description:
You are required to research, write, and record a podcast (video) of 6-8 minutes in length introducing tour participants to one of the archaeological sites, monuments, or museum collections we will be visiting on the tour. Topics will be assigned by the course instructors. Video files of all podcasts will be made available for all tour participants to watch and you should be prepared to receive and answer follow-up questions from fellow students while in Italy.

Although the precise content of each podcast will depend on the topic, typically your podcast should outline the history and significance of the site/monument/collection, identify some particularly significant features, and suggest how the site/monument/collection contributes to our understanding of ancient history. Your podcast should be based on scholarly works and official information (e.g. museum websites), and all resources used (including any AI tools) must be referenced in a written transcript and bibliography. Podcasts can be recorded using Zoom, Microsoft PowerPoint, or similar software. Further guidance will be provided in class and on Blackboard. (Please note: while you will not be assessed on technical aspects of video production, your words must be clearly audible and all images and text must be legible in the recording. You don’t need to appear in the podcast if you don’t want to.)

You must submit your podcast as an MP4 file. You must also submit a written transcript, including references and bibliography, through Turnitin. Your references and bibliography must follow the style set out in the Classics and Ancient History Study Guide and Study Videos.

Following our visit to the place in question, you will be required to submit a written reflection of 250 words (+/- 10%) commenting on how your experience of visiting the site/monument/collection in person compared with your expectations from preparing the podcast, including any additional insights you gained from visiting in person and anything in the podcast that you would have done differently in light of your in-person experience and questions from other students. Your written reflection must be submitted within three calendar days of visiting the site/museum.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
While on tour you will be required to submit a total of six exercises based on sites and museums we visit, comprising three shorter exercises (max. 300 words) and three longer exercises (max. 600 words). A list of exercises will be made available on Blackboard. Many of these involve taking photos, so please ensure you have access to a smartphone with a working camera (or other digital camera) during the tour. Each week’s exercises will be due by 11:59pm Rome time on the Sunday of that week (11, 18, 25 January 2026). 

You are free to choose which exercises you complete each week and which sites/museums you write about, provided that you observe the following rules:

  • You must submit one longer and one shorter exercise in each week of the tour.
  • You must not complete any museum/site exercise on the same topic as your podcast assignment.
  • You must not complete two museum/site exercises based on the same monument/object.
  • You must not complete the same exercise twice (even if you choose different sites/objects).

Please check with course staff if you are unsure whether what you are planning to do complies with these requirements.

Your responses to the exercises must draw on your own experience and observations visiting the sites/museums in question during the study tour. While on site you will need to make notes and take photos which you will use in your submissions. While most of the exercises do not require additional research or referencing, you must reference any resources used, including any AI tools.

The shorter exercises are each worth 5% of your overall mark for the course and the longer exercises are worth 10%.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
While on tour, you are expected to participate in all scheduled activities, engage appropriately with fellow students and staff, and behave at all times in accordance with the UQ Code of Conduct.

As part of your participation in the course, you are expected to:

  • Arrive on time for all tour activities and transport connections;
  • Prepare for site/museum visits by watching the relevant podcast (where available);
  • Listen to content presented by site guides and course staff;
  • Conduct yourself in a courteous and professional manner.

Your Participation and Citizenship mark will also take into account your engagement in discussion of course content with fellow students and staff, quality of contributions, and ability to answer questions on the topic of your podcast.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
